pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This PR unsqueezes all the terminal `simps` and `simpas` in a selection of files under `LSeries`. It results in a 13% slowdown overall, and I leave it up to the maintainers whether this slowdown is a price worth paying for the maintainability advantages.

(The one file which slows down most, ~~LSeries/Basic~~ `LSeries/Dirichlet` (edit: sorry!), seems to be worst affected not because of the simps per se, but because the file doesn't contain much else except definitions and routine API lemmas, so the slowdown from unsqueezing simps looms larger in comparison.)

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: !bench

### PR summary [4555e8bc92](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21133/commits/4555e8bc922792d3cdd3bc85af5a0a6aea0a68b9)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Here are the [benchmark results](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/run-detail/aa2def04-4873-4502-8772-03d69befcb4b) for commit 56e1bddc1b2d0a8f2eb42d50bb532f18b3588a1e.
There were [significant changes](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/compare/568c2780-74f0-4259-bad0-55bdde512c6e/to/aa2def04-4873-4502-8772-03d69befcb4b) against commit c33fe046f64d7570c10713af5fb4ffd95d1d0613:
```diff
  Benchmark                                       Metric         Change
  =====================================================================
- ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Dirichlet         instructions    51.7%
- ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.HurwitzZetaEven   instructions    17.8%
```

|File|Instructions|%|
|-|-:|:-:|
|`build`|+31.338‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+0.02%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.HurwitzZetaEven`|+11.461‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+17.81%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Dirichlet`|+10.639‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+51.70%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.HurwitzZetaOdd`|+7.258‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+14.79%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.HurwitzZetaValues`|+2.689‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+11.29%)|
<details><summary>6 files, Instructions +1.0‚¨ù10‚Åπ</summary>

|File|Instructions|%|
|-|-:|:-:|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.DirichletContinuation`|+1.857‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+7.41%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Linearity`|+1.572‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+14.12%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Convergence`|+1.428‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+15.96%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Convolution`|+1.334‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+12.60%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Basic`|+1.325‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+7.21%)|
|`Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.AbstractFuncEq`|+1.50‚¨ù10‚Åπ|(+1.91%)|
</details>

[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12995294393)

[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13050729298)
I'm not sure I think this is universally good if it makes one of the files 50% slower...

> I'm not sure I think this is universally good if it makes one of the files 50% slower...

I'm not so sure this is a good metric. Per-file percentages are informative for issues that affect whole chunks of the library (like typeclass-synthesis slowness) but here we're talking about lots of localised changes that are completely orthogonal to each other. I used Kim's proposed criterion "anything that takes < 10,000 heartbeats should be left unsqueezed"; I think the slowest of these is 6k heartbeats (and most are much faster than that).
bors d+

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13055021323/job/36423828888)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13055021323/job/36423829454)

The ones where you gain a line are definitely worth unsqueezing (not so much because you gain a line, but because the large `simp only` calls are the most fragile). The ones where you don't could arguably be either way.

The ones where you gain a line are definitely worth unsqueezing (not so much because you gain a line, but because the large `simp only` calls are the most fragile). The ones where you don't could arguably be either way.
Yes, OK üëç
Could we move the note to immediately before the `simpa`?
Sure, done

```suggestion
      simp [Nat.mul_eq_zero, -singleton_prod, -prod_singleton]
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(NumberTheory/LSeries): unsqueeze lots of terminal simps
